Copy No. 39CP. 268 (30).[W 6956/103/50]CABINET.CEREMONIES IN CONNECTION WITH FOREIGN WAR MEMORIALS. MEMORANDUM BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS. ON the 17th December, 1929 (see Cabinet Conclusions 53 (29)), the cabinet had before them a memorandum in which it was suggested that the time had now come for discontinuing the practice of placing wreaths on foreign war memorialsand official participation in all such ceremonies abroad. The Cabinet decided thatthe Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, without at that stage formally proposing the discontinuance of the above practices, should take such steps as he might deemappropriate to sound foreign nations on the subject with a view to discontinuanceif the replies were favourable. In accordance with this decision, I instructed His Majesty's Representatives at paris, Rome, Brussels, Lisbon, Warsaw, Prague, Bucharest, Belgrade, Athens, Tokyoand Washington to sound unofficially the Governments to which they are accredited,and ascertain whether they would favour the discontinuance of the exchange of this form of international courtesy. I have now received the observations of all the Governments addressed, andthere is a general consensus of opinion that it would be desirable to dispense with theceremonies in question. I need only quote one of these replies, namely, that from paris. The French Ministry for Foreign Affairs informed the British Embassythat they entirely agree with these proposals. In fact, the French authorities, bothcivil, military and naval, have suffered much from the abuse of the practice of placingwreaths on war memorials. Whenever ceremonies of this kind are carried out inFrance it is necessary for one or more officers to be present, and a considerable amountof their time is thus occupied. The French Government would therefore be glad to see the practice discontinued. In these circumstances I suggest that His Majesty's Representatives in thecountries of all the former Allied and Associated Powers should be instructed to address the Governments to which they are accredited officially proposing that thepractice be discontinued. Next Armistice Day might be suggested as the date for thebeginning of the new arrangement. I suggest also that, out of courtesy, ex-enemy countries should be informed at the same time I attach hereto the draft of a despatch which might be sent to His Majesty's Representatives on the subject. Acopy might be sent to His Majesty's Representatives in ex-enemy countries, with instructions to inform those Governments of the proposals. A. H. July 22, 1930.Draft Despatch to His Majesty's Representatives in the Countries of Former Allied and A ssociated Powers.Sir, It has been represented to His Majesty's Government that the time has now come when probably in all the countries involved in the Great War general feelingwould be in favour of discontinuing the practice of placing wreaths on foreign warmemorials and official participation in all such ceremonies abroad. 5494 [21428J 2. For the purpose of ascertaining whether this impression was correct I madeunofficial enquiries at certain capitals during the early part of this year, and I havenow ascertained that in as many as eleven countries the Governments would be content to see these practices abandoned. 3. I accordingly request that you will inform the Government to which you are accredited that His Majesty's Government understand that there is now a general,consensus of opinion that the time has come to discontinue the exchange of this formof international courtesy, and His Majesty's Government, for their part, accordinglypropose to discontinue the practice. If, as His Majesty's Government hope, theGovernment to which you are accredited share their views, they would suggest that a convenient date for bringing the new arrangement into force would be the11th November next. 4. This despatch has been addressed to His Majesty's Representatives in thecountries of all the former Allied and Associated Powers.
